title: The First Speech Synthesizer
content: In 1779, Christian Kratzenstein built one of the first speech synthesizers - a set of resonating tubes that could produce vowel sounds when air was blown through them. It was remarkably accurate for its time!

title: The Discovery of Formants
content: In the 1950s, researchers discovered that vowels could be characterized by their formant frequencies - specific resonances in the vocal tract. This insight revolutionized both speech science and synthesis.

title: The Peterson-Barney Study
content: The Peterson & Barney (1952) study measured formant frequencies from 76 speakers. Their vowel charts are STILL used today to teach phonetics, over 70 years later!

title: The Birth of the Spectrogram
content: During WWII, engineers at Bell Labs developed the sound spectrograph to analyze encrypted speech. After the war, it became the speech scientist's most important tool for visualizing sound.

title: McGurk Effect Discovery
content: In 1976, Harry McGurk discovered that what we SEE affects what we HEAR. When watching someone say 'ga' while hearing 'ba', most people perceive 'da'. Vision and hearing integrate automatically!

title: The Source-Filter Theory
content: Gunnar Fant's source-filter theory (1960) explained how speech is produced: a sound source (vocal folds) filtered by the vocal tract shape. This model is still the foundation of speech science today!

title: Coarticulation Discovery
content: Researchers discovered that we don't produce speech sounds in isolation - each sound is influenced by neighboring sounds. This 'coarticulation' makes speech production efficient but recognition challenging!

title: The Cocktail Party Effect
content: Colin Cherry (1953) described how we can focus on one conversation in a noisy room full of people talking. This launched decades of research into selective attention and speech perception.

title: Voice Onset Time
content: Researchers discovered that the difference between 'pa' and 'ba' is just timing - how long between lip opening and vocal fold vibration. VOT became crucial for understanding speech perception categories.

title: Mel Frequency Scale
content: In the 1930s, Stevens and Volkmann showed that our perception of pitch isn't linear - the mel scale was born! This perceptual scale is now fundamental to speech processing and voice technology.
